abstracts.cdata!:
The Treasury Systems Project for Ukraine
            had the following ratings: the outcome was satisfactory, the
            sustainability was likely, the institutional development
            impact was substantial, and the Bank and borrower
            performance were both satisfactory. The lessons learned
            indicate that government commitment to reform over the
            entire project duration, which has extended to seven years,
            has been a critical success factor for this project. In the
            design of this project, attention was carefully focused on
            functional design issues prior to computerization issues, to
            ensure effective and efficient implementation. The
            partnership between the Bank and the Fiscal Affairs
            Department (FAD) of the IMF in terms of delivery of
            coordinated policy advice, close monitoring and follow-up
            has been critical for successful project implementation. The
            Government's ability to staff the project team with an
            extremely competent project manager and with a dedicated
            team of Treasury staff was critical during the testing and
            implementation phases of the new system. The project closing
            date had to be extended by two and a half years to complete
            the project activities. A focused and well-defined program
            and a single implementing agency are prerequisites to
            successful and smooth implementation.

5083263.majtheme: Public sector governance,Financial and private sector development,Rule of law

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall objective of the Treasury
            Systems Project is to support ongoing Government efforts to
            design and implement a fully functional, automated treasury
            system, that will service as an effective instrument for
            budget execution and cash management.  The project will
            provide technical assistance, computer equipment, software,
            and training to enable the authorities to design, develop,
            test, and implement processes, procedures, and systems,
            related regulations and training programs for budget
            execution and payroll management. The reforms will include:
            a) development of a budget management law; b) adoption of a
            budget classification system; c) implementing a transaction
            based treasury ledger system; d) centralizing government
            payments; e) reducing reliance on physical movements of cash
            including implementing a direct deposit payroll system; and
            f) conducting a functional review of the Treasury
            Department.  The project will first assist in system design.
            The system will then be implemented at a number of pilot
            sites and, after the pilot exercise, replicated across the country.
